Dharma Pearls

Translating Classical Buddhism to Modern English

What's New Translations Resources About

The Medium Discourses

(Skt. Madhyama Āgama; Ch. 中阿含經)

The Medium Discourses was translated twice to Chinese; the second translation is the one that survives today. Completed in the late 4th century CE, it appears to represent the Sarvâstivāda version of the collection. The Pali equivalent is the Majjhima Nikāya, but the two collections differ somewhat in both their arrangement and the texts chosen. With a total 212 sutras, the Medium Discourses contains many texts that appear in the Pali Aṅguttara Nikāya and some that don't appear to exist in Pali. The collection is divided into five recitations and 18 thematic chapters.

Below is a list of the chapters of the The Medium Discourses. Those with links have translations available.

  • I. First Recitation
    1. The Sevens
      1. The Good Dharma
      2. The Pārijāta Tree
      3. The City Parable
      4. The Water Parable
      5. The Wood Pile Parable
      6. The Good Person’s Departure
      7. Worldly Merit
      8. Seven Suns
      9. Seven Chariots
      10. Ending the Contaminants
    2. Related to Action
      1. The Rock Salt Parable
      2. [Vappa]
      3. Liberation
      4. Rāhula
      5. Intention
      6. The Kālāmas
      7. [Gamini]
      8. The Lion
      9. Nirgrantha
      10. [Pāṭali]
    3. Related to Śāriputra
      1. Equanimity
      2. Accomplishing the Precepts
      3. Knowledge
      4. The Lion’s Roar
      5. The Water Parable (2)
      6. [Gulissāni]
      7. [Dhānañjani]
      8. Edifying the Ill
      9. Mahākauṣṭhila
      10. Parable of the Elephant’s Footprint
      11. Discernment of the Noble Truths
    1. Related to Cultivation
      1. What Purpose
      2. Don’t Think
      3. Mindfulness

      5. Conscience and Modesty (2)
      6. Precepts
